'''Kai Simons''' (born 24 May 1938) is a [[Finns|Finnish]] professor of [[biochemistry]] and [[cell biology]] living and working in [[Germany]]. Author of the concept of [[lipid rafts]]<ref name="pmid9177342">{{cite journal |vauthors=Simons K, Ikonen E |title=Functional rafts in cell membranes |journal=Nature |volume=387 |issue=6633 |pages=569–72 |year=1997 |pmid=9177342 |doi=10.1038/42408 |url=}}</ref> coined also the term ''[[trans-Golgi network]]'' and proposed its role in protein and lipid sorting,<ref name="pmid2945253">{{cite journal |vauthors=Griffiths G, Simons K |title=The trans Golgi network: sorting at the exit site of the Golgi complex |journal=Science |volume=234 |issue=4775 |pages=438–43 |year=1986 |pmid=2945253 |doi= 10.1126/science.2945253|url=}}</ref> Co-founder and co-organizer of [[European Molecular Biology Laboratory|EMBO]], [[European Molecular Biology Organization|ELSO]], initiated the foundation of [[Max Planck Institute of Molecular Cell Biology and Genetics|MPI-CBG]],<ref name="pmid19114590">{{Cite journal|last=Simons|first=Kai|date=2008-12-29|title=Kai Simons: membrane master|journal=The Journal of Cell Biology|volume=183|issue=7|pages=1180–1181|doi=10.1083/jcb.1837pi|issn=1540-8140|pmc=2606959|pmid=19114590}}</ref> where he acted as a director (1998–2006) and a group-leader (until 2012).<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.mpi-cbg.de/institute/directors/|title=MPI-CBG: Directors|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Max Planck Institute of Molecular Cell Biology and Genetics|access-date=2016-07-26}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.mpi-cbg.de/research-groups/alumni/|title=MPI-CBG: Alumni|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Max Planck Institute of Molecular Cell Biology and Genetics|access-date=2016-07-26}}</ref> Co-founder and co-owner of Lipotype GmbH.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.lipotype.com/about-us/|title=Everything you should know ABOUT US|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Lipotype GmbH|access-date=2016-07-26}}</ref>
== Biography == Kai Simons is a son of [[physics]] professor. It was his father, who convinced him to study [[medicine]], however in the beginning Simons wanted to study physics.<ref name="pmid19114590" /> While studying in [[University of Helsinki]], Simons spent a summer internship in [[Stockholm]] laboratory of [[Bengt Samuelsson]]<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ascb.org/ascb-members-profile-archives/|title=ASCB Members Profile Archives - Kai Simons|last=|first=|date=2009-08-13|website=|publisher=The American Society for Cell Biology|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070715061747/http://www.ascb.org/index.cfm?navid=110&id=1331&tcode=nws3|archive-date=2007-07-15|access-date=2016-07-27}}</ref> Simons worked there on mechanisms of [[vitamin B12]] absorption<ref name="pmid19114590" /> In his student's years together with fellow students he organized anti-[[taeniasis]] campaign, the disease common in the eastern Finland where eating raw [[fish]] is popular.<ref name=":3" />
After completing his PhD in medicine in 1964, he began a [[postdoctoral fellowship]] at [[Rockefeller University]] in [[New York City|New York]] where he worked between 1966 and 1967 on [[blood serum]] [[protein]] [[Polymorphism (biology)|polymorphism]]<ref name="pmid19114590" /> He came back to Helsinki in 1967, where he started to work as a Junior Investigator for the Finnish Medical Research Council at the [[University of Helsinki]].<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://www.mpi-cbg.de/research-groups/current-groups/kai-simons/group-leader.html|title=Kai Simons|last=|first=|date=|website=MPI CBG Research Group -: Group Leader|publisher=Max Planck Institute of Molecular Cell Biology and Genetics|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> He became a group leader in 1972 and was a biochemistry professor in 1971–79 at the medical faculty of this university<ref name=":4" /> In the beginning he continued his work on serum proteins. Next, together with [[Leevi Kääriäinen]] and [[Ossi Renkonen]], he started a research team - later joined by [[Ari Helenius]], his first PhD student and later a post doctoral researcher who became Simons' [[brother-in-law]]. After one-month stay in [[Laboratory of Molecular Biology|MRC Laboratory for Molecular Biology]] in [[Cambridge]], the group started investigating a [[Semliki Forest virus]], introduced to Simons by Kääriäinenem.<ref name="pmid19114590" />
In 1975 Simons came to [[Heidelberg]] (Germany), as one of the [[European Molecular Biology Laboratory|EMBL]] group leaders. Together with Ari Helenius he helped to develop EMBL, headed at this time by [[John Kendrew]].<ref name="pmid19114590" /> In years 1982–1998 Simons was a coordinator of the Cell Biology Program there.<ref name=":4" /> During this time he for the first time presented the concept of [[lipid rafts]].
In 1999 he took part in setting up [[European Molecular Biology Organization|ELSO]] (later incorporated into [[European Molecular Biology Organization|EMBO]]), which later he presided over.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gransalke|first=Kathleen|date=2014|title=There Are No Easy Solutions|url=http://www.labtimes.org/epaper/LT_14_04.pdf|journal=Lab Times|volume=4|issue=|pages=34–37|doi=|issn=1864-2381|pmid=|access-date=2016-07-27|via=}}</ref>
He was one of the initiators of establishing and building [[Max Planck Institute of Molecular Cell Biology and Genetics]] in [[Dresden]] ([[Germany]]), where he moved. Formally from 1998 (beginning of MPI-CBG construction) and practically from 2000 he was one of five institute's directors and also a group leader there<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> Since 2006 he is a ''director emeritus''.<ref name=":0" />
In 2012 he started-up a [[biotech company]] Lipotype GmbH, where he is a [[CEO]].<ref name=":2" />
He is married to Carola Simons and a father of three: twins - Mikael ([[neurobiology|neurobiologist]]) and Katja ([[sociology|sociologist]] and [[spatial planning]]), and the youngest of three, Matias (physician).<ref name=":3" />
== Work == In the beginning Kai Simons pursued research in the field of medical biochemistry and his [[master's thesis]] as well as PhD focused on vitamin B12 absorption.<ref name="pmid19114590" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Grasbeck|first=R.|last2=Runeberg|first2=L.|last3=Simons|first3=K.|date=1959-12-12|title=Intrinsic factor and radiovitamin B12 excretion in rats|journal=Acta Physiologica Scandinavica|volume=47|pages=370–374|issn=0001-6772|pmid=13828995}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Grasbeck|first=R.|last2=Simons|first2=K.|last3=Sinkkonen|first3=I.|date=1962-01-01|title=Purification of intrinsic factor and vitamin B12 binders from human gastric juice|journal=Annales Medicinae Experimentalis et Biologiae Fenniae|volume=40(Suppl 6)|pages=1–24|issn=0003-4479|pmid=13949889}}</ref> After returning from his post-doc scholarship he continued research on vitamin B12 as well as on [[Blood proteins|blood plasma proteins]], but soon started investigating Semliki Forest virus, focusing on its [[biological membrane|membrane]] and its [[lipids|lipid]] composition and their role in the [[Viral shedding|virus budding]] and its transport, as the model for lipid and [[protein secretion]].<ref name="pmid19114590" /><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Renkonen O, Gahmberg CG, Kaariainen L, Simons K |title=Envelope of Semliki Forest virus as membrane model |journal=Biochem. J. |volume=128 |issue=1 |pages=20P–21P |year=1972 |pmid=5085567 |pmc=1173622 |doi= |url=}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Renkonen O, Kääriäinen L, Gahmberg CG, Simons K |title=Lipids of Semliki Forest virus and of host cell membranes |journal=Biochem. Soc. Symp. |volume= |issue=35 |pages=407–22 |year=1972 |pmid=4614812 |doi= |url=}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Simons K, Garoff H |title=The budding mechanisms of enveloped animal viruses |journal=J. Gen. Virol. |volume=50 |issue=1 |pages=1–21 |year=1980 |pmid=6255080 |doi=10.1099/0022-1317-50-1-1 |url=}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Simons K, Warren G |title=Semliki Forest virus: a probe for membrane traffic in the animal cell |journal=Adv. Protein Chem. |volume=36 |issue= |pages=79–132 |year=1984 |pmid=6382965 |doi= |url=}}</ref> During this period, Simons also investigated the application of [[detergents]] in biochemistry with a special attention to their role in biological membrane research.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Helenius A, Simons K |title=Solubilization of membranes by detergents |journal=Biochim. Biophys. Acta |volume=415 |issue=1 |pages=29–79 |year=1975 |pmid=1091302 |doi= 10.1016/0304-4157(75)90016-7|url=}}</ref>
The virus [[Biological life cycle|lifecycle]] and how it uses components of [[Vesicle (biology and chemistry)|vesicular]] pathways while shuttling to the cell surface, turned Simons' attention toward vesicular transport pathways and [[Cell polarity|cell polarization]]. Applying [[epithelium|epithelial]] [[Cell culture|model cells]] - [[Madin-Darby Canine Kidney cells|MDCK]] (Madin-Darby canine kidney), he investigated lipid transport, protein sorting and their role in polarizing cells.<ref name="pmid19114590" /><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Simons K, Fuller SD |title=Cell surface polarity in epithelia |journal=Annu. Rev. Cell Biol. |volume=1 |issue= |pages=243–88 |year=1985 |pmid=3939606 |doi=10.1146/annurev.cb.01.110185.001331 |url=}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Simons K |title=Membrane traffic in an epithelial cell line derived from the dog kidney |journal=Kidney Int. Suppl. |volume=23 |issue= |pages=S201–10 |year=1987 |pmid=2831424 |doi= |url=}}</ref>
During these studies he described the role of [[trans-Golgi network]] (TGN) in protein and lipid sorting according to their destination.<ref name="pmid2945253" /><ref name="pmid19114590" /> In his works from 1988, together with [[Gerit van Meer]],<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=van Meer G, Simons K |title=Lipid polarity and sorting in epithelial cells |journal=J. Cell. Biochem. |volume=36 |issue=1 |pages=51–8 |year=1988 |pmid=3277985 |doi=10.1002/jcb.240360106 |url=}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Simons K, van Meer G |title=Lipid sorting in epithelial cells |journal=Biochemistry |volume=27 |issue=17 |pages=6197–202 |year=1988 |pmid=3064805 |doi= 10.1021/bi00417a001|url=}}</ref> Simons for the first time postulated the existence of lipid microdomains in [[cell membrane]]s.<ref name="pmid19114590" /> Such microdomains differ in their composition from the surrounding membrane and have special functions. Simons termed these microdomains as [[lipid rafts]]. This concept was developed over the years to be presented more fully in 1997 in ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]'' journal by Simons and Ikonen.<ref name="pmid9177342" /> This paper became one of the most frequently cited works in the field of membrane research. Other Simons' paper, on role of lipid rafts in the [[signal transduction]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Simons|first=K.|last2=Toomre|first2=D.|date=2000-10-01|title=Lipid rafts and signal transduction|journal=Nature Reviews. Molecular Cell Biology|volume=1|issue=1|pages=31–39|doi=10.1038/35036052|issn=1471-0072|pmid=11413487}}</ref> is second highest cited work and Simons is fourth highest cited scientist in the field of signal transduction. Kai Simons was also recognized by [[ISI Web of Knowledge]], as one of the most cited scientist ever.
In next years, Simons continued to work on the role of lipid rafts, and more generally lipids, in cell polarization and protein sorting.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Klemm|first=Robin W.|last2=Ejsing|first2=Christer S.|last3=Surma|first3=Michal A.|last4=Kaiser|first4=Hermann-Josef|last5=Gerl|first5=Mathias J.|last6=Sampaio|first6=Julio L.|last7=de Robillard|first7=Quentin|last8=Ferguson|first8=Charles|last9=Proszynski|first9=Tomasz J.|date=2009-05-18|title=Segregation of sphingolipids and sterols during formation of secretory vesicles at the trans-Golgi network|journal=The Journal of Cell Biology|volume=185|issue=4|pages=601–612|doi=10.1083/jcb.200901145|issn=1540-8140|pmc=2711577|pmid=19433450|url=https://dash.harvard.edu/bitstream/handle/1/4513029/2711577.pdf?sequence=1}}</ref> He was interested also in the role of lipids and protein sorting in [[neurodegenerative diseases]], especially in [[Alzheimer's disease]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rajendran|first=Lawrence|last2=Honsho|first2=Masanori|last3=Zahn|first3=Tobias R.|last4=Keller|first4=Patrick|last5=Geiger|first5=Kathrin D.|last6=Verkade|first6=Paul|last7=Simons|first7=Kai|date=2006-07-25|title=Alzheimer's disease beta-amyloid peptides are released in association with exosomes|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America|volume=103|issue=30|pages=11172–11177|doi=10.1073/pnas.0603838103|issn=0027-8424|pmc=1544060|pmid=16837572}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rajendran|first=Lawrence|last2=Schneider|first2=Anja|last3=Schlechtingen|first3=Georg|last4=Weidlich|first4=Sebastian|last5=Ries|first5=Jonas|last6=Braxmeier|first6=Tobias|last7=Schwille|first7=Petra|last8=Schulz|first8=Jörg B.|last9=Schroeder|first9=Cornelia|date=2008-04-25|title=Efficient inhibition of the Alzheimer's disease beta-secretase by membrane targeting|journal=Science |volume=320|issue=5875|pages=520–523|doi=10.1126/science.1156609|issn=1095-9203|pmid=18436784}}</ref>
His scientific record includes more than 350 [[scientific article]]s, mostly in the field of biochemistry, molecular organization of the cell, and biochemistry and physiology of a cell membrane.
Considering his work from years 1996–2007 tracked until May 2009, Simons was 12. in the list of the most frequently cited scientists in the field [[cell biology]] with 90 articles and 16,299 citations.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Neumann|first=Ralf|date=2009|title=Publication Analysis 1996-2007. Cell Biology|url=http://www.lab-times.org/labtimes/issues/lt2009/lt05/lt_2009_05_42_44.pdf|journal=Lab Times|volume=5|issue=|pages=42–44|doi=|issn=1864-2381|pmid=|access-date=2016-07-27|via=}}</ref>

'''Libertarian management''' is participative and/or non-authoritarian self-management, which typically emphasizes repetition of proven successes, institutional learning, and earmarking funds to project investment. Libertarian consultants generally focus on management and system productivity, not worker productivity. Libertarian management exponents believe the method can be applied beyond industrial settings in areas such as alternate family arrangements, [[co-housing]], and the [[cooperative]] movement.
While no text on the subject exists, libertarian management has been highly influential as a guiding concept among American Libertarian founders of [[intentional communities]] and American management productivity [[consultant]]s. Noted proponents of libertarian management include [[W. Edwards Deming]] and [[Peter Drucker]]. Many companies use the concepts and techniques of libertarian management, some of which are listed below.{{citation needed|date=December 2011}}
==Libertarian management and the US Libertarian Party==
The last three chairs{{which?|date=April 2014}} of the [[Libertarian Party (United States)|United States Libertarian Party]] have worked as management consultants. Members of the Party often{{quantify|date=April 2014}} refer to organizations using Libertarian management as "do-cracies" - systems which emphasize decision-making by the initiators and implementers (i.e. doers) of a [[project]]. Typically, decisions in such a do-ocracy come about through a [[Consensus decision-making|consensus]] process.
==Concepts of libertarian management==
* Desirable definition processes * User [[co-operatives]] * Building quality in * [[Learning circles]] * Thinking squares * Emoting trapezoids * Philosophizing ellipses * [[Gainsharing]] * [[Modular businesses]] * [[Open source]] * [[Business process reengineering|Re-engineering]] * Bottom-up [[strategic planning]] * Tactical [[best practices]] * [[Open-book management]] and learning * Detailed activity and task lists and standards * [[Outcome metrics]] * Short interval check scheduling and control * Management by worker created objectives * Self-managing task creation and assignment * [[Goal analysis]] * [[Management engineering]] * Re-[[privatization]] of government services * Standards definition and organization * [[Prototyping]] * [[Internal markets]]

{{Use American English|date=August 2018}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2018}} [[Acclaim Entertainment]] was an American [[video game publisher]] from [[Long Island]], active from 1987 until filing for [[Chapter 7 bankruptcy]] on September 1, 2004. Through a series of acquisitions between 1990 and 2002, Acclaim built itself a large portfolio of subsidiaries acting in the fields of development and publishing.
== Development ==
=== Acclaim Studios === Acclaim Studios was established in July 1998 to organize all Acclaim-owned development studios under one management.<ref>https://www.bizjournals.com/austin/stories/1998/07/27/daily13.html</ref> In May 1999, all underlying studios were uniformly rebranded to bear the "Acclaim Studios" prefix.<ref name="rebranding">{{cite web |url=https://www.thefreelibrary.com/Acclaim+Studios+Evolves+into+a+Single+Worldwide+Entity;+Internal...-a054615013 |title=Acclaim Studios Evolves into a Single Worldwide Entity; Internal Development Cornerstone of Product Success. - Free Online Library |author= |date= |website=www.thefreelibrary.com |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref> Acclaim Studios and all of its development facilities were closed on August 27, 2004.<ref name="closure">{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2004/08/27/acclaim-closes-offices |title=Acclaim Closes Offices |first=Douglass C. |last=Perry |date=August 27, 2004 |website=ign.com |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref>
=== Acclaim Studios Austin === {{Main|Acclaim Studios Austin}}
=== Acclaim Studios Cheltenham === '''Acclaim Studios Cheltenham''' was based in [[Cheltenham]], England. The studio was founded in 2000 by former employees of [[Psygnosis]]' South West studio.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.gamespot.com/articles/first-look-extreme-g-3/1100-2693074/ |title=First look: Extreme-G 3 |first=Axel |last=Strohm |date=June 26, 2001 |website=gamespot.com |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref> Acclaim Studios Cheltenham was closed alongside Acclaim's other development facilities on August 27, 2004.<ref name="closure" />
=== Acclaim Studios London === '''Acclaim Studios London''' was based in [[Croydon]], England. The company was founded in 1984 by Fergus McGovern and Vakis Paraskeva under the name Probe Software,<ref name="retrogamer">{{cite web |url=https://www.retrogamer.net/blog_post/sinclair-zx-spectrum-vega-plus-smashes-target/ |title=Sinclair ZX Spectrum Vega Plus Smashes Target - Retro Gamer |author= |date= |website=retrogamer.net |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref> which was later renamed Probe Entertainment.<ref name="eurogamer.net">{{cite web |url=https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2016-02-29-probe-software-founder-fergus-mcgovern-passes-away |title=Probe Software founder Fergus McGovern passes away |author= |date= |website=eurogamer.net |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref> By 1988, the company employed 72 people.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://archive.org/stream/AmstradComputerUser200786/AmstradComputerUser/AmstradComputerUser45-0888#page/n23 |title=Amstrad Computer User 01-90 (Aug 84 - May 92) |author= |date= |publisher= |accessdate=August 26, 2018 |via=Internet Archive}}</ref> Several games developed by Probe included references to McGovern's name or likenes, including the sentence "Is that you, Fergus?" presented to players of ''[[Trantor: The Last Stormtrooper]]'' upon gaining a low score.<ref name="retrogamer" /> The company specialized in the development of [[arcade game]]s and movie [[tie-ins]], including ''[[Out Run]]'', ''[[Mortal Kombat]]'' and ''[[FIFA Soccer]]''.<ref name="theguardian">{{cite web |url=http://www.theguardian.com/technology/2008/jun/24/fergus.mcgovern |title=Fergus McGovern: The games whizzkid who had everything |first=Bobbie |last=Johnson |date=June 24, 2008 |website=the Guardian |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref>
On October 11, 1995, Acclaim announced that they had agreed to acquire Probe for an undisclosed sum.<ref name="nytimes">{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/11/business/company-briefs-055697.html |title=COMPANY BRIEFS |author= |date= |website=nytimes.com |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref> The deal closed later that year, with a rumored transaction of {{US$|40 million}}, making McGovern a millionaire.<ref name="theguardian" /> The same year, McGovern also received a Lifetime Achievement Award for his work at Probe.<ref name="theguardian" /> McGovern left the company a few years later to found [[HotGen]], also a video game developer.<ref name="eurogamer.net"/><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/2016-02-29-obituary-fergus-mcgovern |title=Obituary: Fergus McGovern |author= |date= |website=gamesindustry.biz |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref> With the consolidation of Acclaim Studios' branding in May 1999, Probe was renamed Acclaim Studios London.<ref name="rebranding" /> Acclaim Studios London was closed in April 2000.<ref name="gamekult" />
=== Acclaim Studios Manchester === {{Main|Acclaim Studios Manchester}} Acclaim Studios Manchester was founded in Manchester as Software Creations, a sole trader company, by Richard Kay in 1985.<ref name="Retro Gamer 122">{{cite magazine |title=Bubbles, Baseball and Buzz Saws... |first=Mike |last=Bevan |magazine=[[Retro Gamer]] |issue=122 |date=December 2013 |publisher=[[Imagine Publishing]] |pages=74–79}}</ref> The following year, the company was joined by Steve Ruddy, who began working on [[Commodore 64]] conversions of games like ''[[Mystery of the Nile (video game)|Mystery of the Nile]]'' and ''[[Kinetik (video game)|Kinetik]]''.<ref name="Retro Gamer 122" /> Subsequently, further employees, including the Follin brothers and Mike Ager, followed after Ruddy and joined Software Creations.<ref name="Retro Gamer 122" /> Successful titles produced or ported by Software Creations include ''[[Bubble Bobble]]'' (1987), ''[[Bionic Commando (arcade)|Bionic Commando]]'' (1988), and ''[[Tin Star (video game)|Tin Star]]'' (1994).<ref name="Retro Gamer 122" /> After developing ports of ''[[Ghouls 'n Ghosts]]'' and ''[[LED Storm]]'' in 1989, Software Creations moved into custom-built offices located within Manchester.<ref name="Retro Gamer 122" /> The Pickford brothers, John and Ste, joined the company in 1990, producing ''[[Equinox (1993 video game)|Equinox]]'' and ''[[Plok]]''.<ref name="Retro Gamer 122" /> In 1994, Software Creations was acquired by [[BCE Multimedia]] and became part of [[Rage Software]].<ref name="Retro Gamer 122" />
On May 1, 2002, Acclaim announced that they had acquired Software Creations, which was renamed Acclaim Studios Manchester.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2002/05/01/acclaim-acquires-new-studio |title=Acclaim Acquires New Studio |first=I. G. N. |last=Staff |date=May 1, 2002 |website=ign.com |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/article_45868 |title=Acclaim Studios Manchester formed |author= |date= |website=eurogamer.net |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref> At the time, Software Creations had approximately 70 employees.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/1163/Acclaim_Launches_New_Studio_In_Manchester_UK.php |title=Acclaim Launches New Studio In Manchester, UK |author= |date= |website=gamasutra.com |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref> Acclaim Studios Manchester was closed as part of Acclaim Studios and all of its development facilities on August 27, 2004.<ref name="closure" /> Rod Cousens and Barry Jafrato, who served as [[chief executive officer]] and head of publishing, respectively, for Acclaim, announced in September 2004 that they were planning to create as new video game publisher, Exclaim, with the help of Europlay Capital Advisers.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/95322/Rod_Cousens_Reclaims_UK_Acclaim_Studios.php |title=Gamasutra - The Art & Business of Making Games |first=David |last=Jenkins |date= |website=www.gamasutra.com |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref> Exclaim was set to acquire and reinstantiate Acclaim's two UK studios, namely Manchester and Cheltenham, and re-employ their roughly 160.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/news011004acclaimboss |title=Former Acclaim boss in rescue bid for UK studios |author= |date= |website=eurogamer.net |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref> Exclaim's opening was expected on October 11,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/acclaim-ceos-new-company-plans-to-launch-next-week |title=Acclaim CEO's new company plans to launch next week |author= |date= |website=gamesindustry.biz |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref> however, Cousen's ownership over the two studios was challenged by Acclaim's liquidator, Allan Mendelsohn, leaving the UK staff in a state of limbo.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/acclaim-uk-studios-future-unclear-as-exclaim-deal-stalls |title=Acclaim UK studios' future unclear as Exclaim deal stalls |author= |date= |website=gamesindustry.biz |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref> A successor to Acclaim Studios Manchester, SilverBack Studios, was founded by Jon Oldham in April 2005 and employed 15 former Acclaim Studios Manchester staff.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/news030505acclaimsilverback |title=Former Acclaim title returns |author= |date= |website=eurogamer.net |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/silverback-studios-launches-from-the-ashes-of-acclaim-uk |title=SilverBack Studios launches from the ashes of Acclaim UK |author= |date= |website=gamesindustry.biz |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref>
=== Acclaim Studios Salt Lake City === '''Acclaim Studios Salt Lake City''' was based in [[Salt Lake City, Utah]]. The company was founded by George Matos, [[Bryan Brandenburg]], Peter Adams, Mike Macris and Bob Burgener,<ref name="desert">{{cite web |url=https://www.deseretnews.com/article/472089/ONCE-STRUGGLING-SL-VIDEO-FIRM-HITS-THE-BIG-TIME.html |title=ONCE-STRUGGLING S.L. VIDEO FIRM HITS THE BIG TIME |author= |date=February 18, 1996 |website=deseretnews.com |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref> and incorporated on July 12, 1985.<ref name="findlaw">{{cite web |url=https://caselaw.findlaw.com/ut-supreme-court/1366656.html |title=FindLaw's Supreme Court of Utah case and opinions. |author= |date= |website=Findlaw |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref> Significant games developed by Sculptured Software include ''[[NHL Stanley Cup (Super NES)|NHL Stanley Cup]]'', ''[[WWF Super WrestleMania]]'', the [[Super Nintendo Entertainment System]] conversion of ''[[Doom (1993 video game)|Doom]]'', and ''[[Super Star Wars: The Empire Strikes Back]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.gameinformer.com/b/features/archive/2010/04/16/an-avalanche-of-information.aspx |title=Avalanche: From Mortal Kombat To Toy Story 3 |author= |date= |website=gameinformer.com |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref>
Acclaim announced on October 11, 1995, that they had acquired Sculptured Software.<ref name="nytimes" /> The deal included a transaction of {{US$|30 million|long=no}} in stock.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/130449/the_end_game_how_top_developers_.php |title=The End Game: How Top Developers Sold Their Studios - Part One |author= |date= |website=gamasutra.com |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref> By February 1996, Sculptured Software employed 140 employees, and all founders but Matos had left the company.<ref name="desert" /> Metos left the company the following year to found [[Kodiak Interactive Software Studios]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.gamespot.com/articles/ea-invests-in-kodiak/1100-2464526/ |title=EA Invests in Kodiak |first=Harley |last=Jebens |date=April 28, 2000 |website=gamespot.com |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref> By December 1997, Sculptured Software was renamed Iguana West.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/1997/12/17/iguana-breaks-the-ice |title=Iguana Breaks the Ice |first=I. G. N. |last=Staff |date=December 16, 1997 |website=ign.com |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/1999/04/02/breaking-into-the-industry-vol-5 |title=Breaking into the Industry Vol. 5 |first=I. G. N. |last=Staff |date=April 1, 1999 |website=ign.com |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref> With the consolidation of Acclaim Studios' branding in May 1999, Iguana West was renamed Acclaim Studios Salt Lake City.<ref name="rebranding" /> Acclaim Studios Salt Lake City was dissolved as a cost-cutting exercise in December 2002.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.gamespot.com/articles/acclaim-closes-salt-lake-city-studio/1100-2901281/ |title=Acclaim closes Salt Lake City studio |first=Giancarlo |last=Varanini |date=December 9, 2002 |website=gamespot.com |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref> Through the closure, 70 employees were laid off and an unannounced title was canceled, while the remaining staff and the development of a third installment in the ''[[Legends of Wrestling]]'' series were shifted to Acclaim Studios Austin.<ref name="gamekult" />
=== Acclaim Studios Stroud === '''Acclaim Studios Stroud''' was formed in July 1999 to focus on the development of [[PlayStation (console)|PlayStation]] games.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.gamespot.com/articles/acclaim-announces-new-studio/1100-2566034/ |title=Acclaim Announces New Studio |first=Sam |last=Kennedy |date=May 9, 2000 |website=gamespot.com |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref> Led by Neil Duffield, the studio's team was made up of 26 staff formerly employed by [[Psygnosis]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.tomshardware.co.uk/acclaim-forms-new-playstation-team,news-664.html |title=Acclaim forms new playstation team |author= |date=July 12, 1999 |website=tomshardware.co.uk |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref>
=== Acclaim Studios Teesside === '''Acclaim Studios Teesside''' was based in [[Stockton-on-Tees]], England.<ref name="spong">{{cite web |url=http://spong.com/press_release/5688/Falcus-Brothers-Complete-15-Years-in-Business |title=Falcus Brothers Complete 15 Years in Business - Timeline Event |author= |date= |website=spong.com |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref> The company was founded in February 1988 by brothers Darren and Jason Falcus, at the time aged 19 and 18, respectively,<ref name="gamestm">https://www.gamestm.co.uk/interviews/in-conversation-with-jason-falcus/</ref> under the name Optimus Software.<ref name="spong" /> The company was originally located in Stockton, where the Falcus brothers were born as well.<ref name="spong" /> Both founders had previously started programming in 1981,<ref name="spong" /> and released their first game, ''[[Castle of Doom (video game)|Castle of Doom]]'', in 1983.<ref name="gamestm" /> Games released by Optimus Software generated retail sales in excess of {{US$|500 million|link=yes}}.<ref name="spong" /> These games included ''[[Big Nose the Caveman]]'' and the ''[[Seymour series|Seymour]]'' series, both of which they developed for [[Codemasters]].<ref name="gamasutra">{{cite web |url=https://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/128669/Worms_Studio_Team17_Amps_Up_Social_Strategy_With_Iguana_Acquisition.php |title=Worms Studio Team17 Amps Up Social Strategy With Iguana Acquisition |first=Eric |last=Caoili |date= |website=gamasutra.com |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref>
In 1993, Optimus Software was acquired by [[Iguana Entertainment]] to undisclosed terms.<ref name="spong" /><ref name="ign">{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2004/12/18/a-retrospective-the-story-of-retro-studios?page=2 |title=A Retrospective: The Story of Retro Studios |author= |date=December 17, 2004 |website=ign.com |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref> Subsequently, the company moved to new offices located in [[Middlesbrough]],<ref name="spong" /> and was renamed Iguana UK.<ref name="ign" /> Iguana Entertainment itself was acquired by Acclaim in 1995, at which point Iguana UK moved back to Stockton.<ref name="gazettelive">{{cite web |url=https://www.gazettelive.co.uk/news/local-news/bites-bytes-theres-huge-appetite-3846887 |title=Bites or bytes, there's a huge appetite for Tees excellence |first=Teesside |last=Live |date=July 21, 2003 |website=gazettelive.co.uk |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref> Under the new banner, Iguana UK and the Falcus brothers developed the ''[[Shadow Man (video game)|Shadow Man]]'' series, [[home console]] versions of various ''[[NBA Jam]]'' titles, and the [[Nintendo 64]] version of ''[[Forsaken (video game)|Forsaken]]''.<ref name="gamasutra" /> With the consolidation of Acclaim Studios' branding in May 1999, Iguana UK was renamed Acclaim Studios Teesside.<ref name="rebranding" /> The Falcus brothers left the company in February 2000 and founded [[Atomic Planet Entertainment]].<ref name="spong" /><ref name="gazettelive" /> At that time, the studio had 75 employees.<ref name="gamestm" /> The studio was closed in May 2002.<ref name="gamekult">{{cite web |url=https://www.gamekult.com/actualite/acclaim-ferme-son-studio-de-salt-lake-22593.html |title=Acclaim ferme son studio de Salt Lake |author= |date=December 16, 2002 |website=gamekult.com |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref>
== Publishing ==
=== Acclaim Coin-Operated Entertainment === '''Acclaim Coin-Operated Entertainment''' was an Acclaim subsidiary based in [[Mountain View, California]],<ref>https://www.arcade-museum.com/manuals-videogames/N/NBAJamExtreme.pdf</ref> that focused on releasing [[coin-operated]] games.<ref name="acoe">{{cite web |url=https://www.gamespot.com/articles/acclaim-joins-arcade-initiative/1100-2462531/ |title=Acclaim Joins Arcade Initiative |first=Harley |last=Jebens |date=April 28, 2000 |website=gamespot.com |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref> Leon Deith served as sales director for the company, as of January 1998.<ref name="acoe" /> Acclaim Coin-Operated Entertainment was closed in March 1998, as Acclaim wanted to shift development resources to Acclaim Studios closer to the company's headquarters in New York City.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.gamespot.com/articles/acclaim-closes-arcade-division/1100-2462860/ |title=Acclaim Closes Arcade Division |first=Chris |last=Johnston |date=April 28, 2000 |website=gamespot.com |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref>
=== Acclaim Comics === {{Main|Valiant Comics}}
=== LJN === '''LJN''' was a toy and video game company located in [[New York City]]. The company was founded in 1970 by [[Jack Friedman]], using funds from his former employer, Norman J. Lewis Associates.<ref name="friedman">{{cite web |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/may/06/local/la-me-jack-friedman-20100506 |title=Jack Friedman dies at 70; toy maker |first=Valerie J. |last=Nelson |date=May 6, 2010 |publisher= |accessdate=August 26, 2018 |via=LA Times}}</ref> Friedman served as [[President (corporate title)|president]] for the company.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/15/business/business-people-head-of-lnj-toys-sees-success-through-et.html |title=BUSINESS PEOPLE; HEAD OF LNJ TOYS SEES SUCCESS THROUGH 'E.T.' |author= |date= |website=nytimes.com |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref> On March 26, 1985, [[MCA Inc.]] agreed to acquire 63% of LJN in exchange for {{US$|39.8 million|long=no}} in stock.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1985-03-27/business/fi-20221_1_mca-stock |title=MCA Agrees to Acquire L.J.N. Toys : Entertainment Firm to Exchange Up to $39.8 Million in Stock |first=KATHRYN |last=HARRIS |date=March 27, 1985 |publisher= |accessdate=August 26, 2018 |via=LA Times}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/03/27/business/mca-acquisition.html |title=MCA Acquisition |author= |date= |website=nytimes.com |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref> The deal closed with a transaction of a total of {{US$|67 million}}.<ref name="nytimes2">{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/09/business/mca-turns-hand-to-acquisitions.html |title=MCA TURNS HAND TO ACQUISITIONS |first=Geraldine |last=Fabrikant |date= |website=nytimes.com |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref> Following the acquisition, LJN's revenue doubled to {{US$|27 million|long=no}} by 1986, and continued to rise into 1987.<ref name="nytimes2" /> However, a faulty toy gun manufactured by LJN caused MCA's profits to fall by 79.5%, to {{US$|8.1 million|long=no}}, in 1987's second quarter.<ref name="latimes">{{cite web |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1990-01-23/business/fi-524_1_ljn-toys |title=MCA to Sell LJN Toys Unit After Losses |first=JUBE SHIVER |last=Jr |date=January 23, 1990 |publisher= |accessdate=August 26, 2018 |via=LA Times}}</ref> The same year, Friedman left the company.<ref name="friedman" /> LJN did not recover, as a result of which MCA announced on January 22, 1990, that they intended to sell the company.<ref name="latimes" /><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/23/business/company-news-mca-taking-loss-in-sale-of-toy-unit.html |title=COMPANY NEWS; MCA Taking Loss In Sale of Toy Unit |author= |date= |website=nytimes.com |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref> MCA agreed to sell LJN to Acclaim, for an undisclosed sum paid in cash and stock, on March 13, 1990.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1990-03-13/business/fi-130_1_toy-gun |title=MCA Agrees to Sell Ailing Toy Unit |first=From a Times Staff |last=Writer |date=March 13, 1990 |publisher= |accessdate=August 26, 2018 |via=LA Times}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/13/business/mca-in-pact-with-acclaim.html |title=MCA in Pact With Acclaim |author= |date= |website=nytimes.com |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref> LJN was dissolved in 1995.{{citation needed|date=August 2018}}
=== Flying Edge === '''Flying Edge''' was a division of Acclaim that was founded in 1992 to publish games on [[Sega]] consoles. The division was dissolved in 1994.{{citation needed|date=August 2018}}
=== Arena Entertainment === '''Arena Entertainment''' was a division formed under [[Mirrorsoft]] to publish games on Sega platforms. Arena was acquired by Acclaim in 1992 and dissolved in 1994.{{citation needed|date=August 2018}}
=== Acclaim Sports === '''Acclaim Sports''' was established as a division of Acclaim in November 1997, as part of a {{US$|4 million|long=no}}–{{US$|6 million|long=no}} [[marketing campaign]] for ''[[NFL Quarterback Club '98]]''.<ref name="adage">{{cite web |url=http://adage.com/article/news/acclaim-pumps-sports-games/30928/ |title=Acclaim pumps up sports games |author= |date= |website=adage.com |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref> Acclaim stated that the creation of the target specifically targeted challenging [[Electronic Arts]]' [[EA Sports]] label.<ref name="adage" /> Bob Picunko was appointed [[director of marketing]] of Acclaim Sports.<ref name="adage" />
=== Club Acclaim === '''Club Acclaim''' was a division of Acclaim announced in January 2000, originally for a line of [[Game Boy Color]] games directed towards a younger audience.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.gamespot.com/articles/acclaim-talks-2000-game-lineup/1100-2446085/ |title=Acclaim Talks 2000 Game Lineup |first=Gamespot |last=Staff |date=April 26, 2000 |website=gamespot.com |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref> Club Acclaim's most successful games were those based on [[Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nintendoworldreport.com/news/6882/the-best-game-evar |title=The best game EVAR! - News |author= |date= |website=Nintendo World Report |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref>
=== AKA Acclaim === '''AKA Acclaim''' was a division of Acclaim that released [[extreme sports]] games. Originally known as Acclaim Max Sports, the division was renamed AKA Acclaim in 2002, and was discontinued in 2003.{{citation needed|date=August 2018}}

{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Lyndall F. Urwick | image =Lyndall Urwick.jpg | caption=Lyndall F. Urwick (1891-1983) | image_size = | birth_date = 3 March 1891 | birth_place = | death_date = 5 December 1983 | death_place = | occupation = [[Author]], [[intellectual]], and [[management consultant]] | spouse = | parents = | children = }} '''Lyndall Fownes Urwick''' (3 March 1891 – 5 December 1983) was a British [[management consultant]] and [[organizational theorist|business thinker]]. He is recognised for integrating the ideas of earlier theorists like [[Henri Fayol]] into a comprehensive theory of management administration.<ref>John Sheldrake (2003) ''Management Theory''. p. 92</ref><ref>[[Derek Salman Pugh]], [[David John Hickson]] (2007) ''Great Writers on Organizations''. p. 148</ref> He wrote an influential book called ''The Elements of Business Administration'', published in 1943.<ref>[[March, James G.]], and [[Herbert Alexander Simon]]. ''Organizations.'' (1958).</ref> With [[Luther Gulick (social scientist)|Luther Gulick]], he founded the academic journal ''[[Administrative Science Quarterly]]''.<ref>James Everett Katz (2011) ''Mobile Communication: Dimensions of Social Policy.'' p. 40</ref>
== Biography == === Youth and military service === Urwick was born in Worcestershire, the son of a partner in Fownes Brothers, a long-established glove-making firm. He was educated at [[Boxgrove Primary School]], [[Repton School]] and [[New College, Oxford|New College]], Oxford, where he read History.
He saw active service in the trenches during the [[First World War]], rising to the rank of Major, and being awarded the [[Military Cross]]. Though he did not himself attend the military [[Staff College]] at Camberley, his respect for military training would affect his outlook on management in later life.<ref name=OUPUrwick />
===Rowntree's===
After the war, he joined his father's business of Fownes Brothers. He was then recruited by [[Seebohm Rowntree]], head of the York chocolate company and progressive philanthropist. Urwick's role involved assisting the modernisation of the company, bringing to bear his own thinking, which had two main influences. One was the work of [[Frederick Winslow Taylor|F.W. Taylor]] with its concept of ''[[scientific management]]'', and the other, counterbalancing it in its emphasis on the humanity of management was [[Mary Parker Follett]], for whom he had great admiration.<ref name=OUPUrwick>E.F.L. Brech, Andrew Thomson, John F. Wilson, ''Lyndall Urwick, Management Pioneer: A Biography'' (New York: Oxford University Press, 2010)</ref>
Urwick's own prolific writings on management truly began in this period. At this time, Urwick, along with his colleague at [[Rowntree's]], [[Oliver Sheldon]], became active members of the [[Taylor Society]].<ref>'Major Urwick', ''Bulletin of the Taylor Society'' (April 1931)</ref><ref name=OUPUrwick /><ref name=Weatherburn />
===International Management Institute===
His growing reputation as a British thinker on management and administration won him appointment in 1928 as Director of the [[International Institute for Management Development|International Management Institute]] in [[Geneva]].<ref name=OUPUrwick />
The Institute may have proven short-lived, closing in 1933,<ref name="Link">[[Charles D. Wrege]], Ronald G. Greenwood, and Sakae Hata, 'The International Management Institute and Political Opposition to its Efforts in Europe, 1925-1934' ''Business and Economic History'' (1987)[http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.392.2216&rep=rep1&type=pdf PDF link]</ref> but it provided Urwick the opportunity not only to lecture widely but to produce his books ''The Meaning of Rationalisation'' (1929) and ''The Management of Tomorrow'' (1933).<ref name=OUPUrwick />
Urwick also produced and disseminated the first European study of [[Elton Mayo]]'s research at the [[Hawthorne Works]] in [[Chicago]] while at the IMI.<ref>International Management Institute, ''Industrial Research at the Western Electric Company Inc. (USA)'' (1931)</ref>
It was also this time that he became particularly keen to promote the writings of [[Henri Fayol]] to an English audience.<ref name=OUPUrwick />
===Management consultancy===
Having returned to Britain, in 1934 Urwick established, with John Orr of [[Charles Bedaux|Bedaux Britain]], a [[management consultancy]] named [[Urwick, Orr & Partners]] (UOP).<ref name=OUPUrwick /><ref>Patricia Tisdall, ''Agents of Change: The Development and Practice of Management Consultancy'' (London: Heinemann, 1982).</ref><ref name=Ferguson>Michael Ferguson, ''The Rise of Management Consulting in Britain'' (Aldershot: Ashgate, 2002)</ref> UOP's slogan was ''Profit on Principle: A British Service for British Business in the application of the Principles of Direction and Control.''<ref name=UOPHistory>Lyndall Urwick Society, ''The Urwick Orr Partnership, 1934-1984'' (privately printed, Lyndall Urwick Society, 2007).</ref><ref name=Weatherburn>Michael R. Weatherburn, 'Scientific Management at Work: the Bedaux System, Management Consulting, and Worker Efficiency in British Industry, 1914-48' (Imperial College PhD thesis, 2014) {{cite journal|url= https://spiral.imperial.ac.uk/handle/10044/1/25296 |title=Download PDF from Imperial College, London |date=July 2014 |last1=Weatherburn |first1=Michael }}</ref>
[[File:Urwick Orr & Partners (1934).jpg|thumb|Urwick Orr & Partners (1934)]]
From the outset, UOP instituted a copy of the [[Bedaux System]] and [[Bedaux Unit]], the ''Point System'', in hundreds of factories and offices across [[United Kingdom|Britain]] and further afield.<ref name=UOPHistory /><ref name=Weatherburn />
Orr left the consultancy in the 1940s, putting Urwick in effective control of the company in the postwar period.<ref name=UOPHistory /> Along with [[Associated Industrial Consultants|AIC]], [[P-E]] and [[PA Consulting]], UOP came to be one of the 'Big Four' leading Western European consultancies in the 1950s.<ref>Matthias Kipping, 'Consultancies, Institutions and the Diffusion of Taylorism in Britain, Germany and France, 1920s to 1950s', ''Business History'' (1997) [http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/00076799700000146 PDF from Taylor & Francis online]</ref><ref name=Ferguson />
A particularly notable UOP [[consultant]] was [[Edward Francis Leopold Brech|E.F.L. Brech]], with whom Urwick wrote the ''[[Making of Scientific Management]]'' trilogy.<ref name=KreisThesis>Steven Kreis, 'The Diffusion of an Idea: A History of Scientific Management in Britain, 1890-1945' (PhD thesis, University of Missouri-Columbia, 1990) [http://www.worldcat.org/title/diffusion-of-an-idea-a-history-of-scientific-management-in-britain-1890-1945/oclc/25526850?referer=di&ht=edition entry on WorldCat]</ref><ref name=UOPHistory />
===Later years===
In the post-war period Urwick appeared on the lecturing circuit on both sides of the [[Atlantic]], including on the [[BBC]].<ref>Lyndall Urwick, 'Individual versus Card-Index' ''The Listener'' (1949)</ref>
Urwick became a well-known enthusiast of management education and management history, and a public promoter of [[Frederick Winslow Taylor|F.W. Taylor]] and [[scientific management]].<ref>Michael Roper, 'Killing Off the Father: Social Science and the Memory of Frederick Taylor in Management Studies, 1950-75' ''Contemporary British History'' (1999).</ref> So much so that [[Harry Braverman]] attacked him in 1974's ''[[Labor and Monopoly Capital]]'' as the 'rhapsodic historian of the scientific management movement'.<ref name="mr">{{cite book |url=http://monthlyreview.org/press/books/pb9401/ |last=Braverman |first=Harry |title=Labor and Monopoly Capital: The Degradation of Work in the Twentieth Century |location=New York |publisher=Monthly Review Press |date=January 1998 |isbn=978-0-85345-940-8}}</ref>
In 1955 Urwick was awarded the [[Wallace Clark Award]]. In later years, Lyndall Urwick retired to [[Australia]], where he died in 1983. His papers were donated to the [[Administrative Staff College]], by then renamed [[Henley Management College]].<ref name=OUPUrwick />
== Work ==
=== ''Making of Scientific Management'' === In 1945, he made his most lasting contribution to management literature with the publication of his three-volume ''Making of Scientific Management''. It was the first treatise to present a clear and focused discussion of the development and applications of management science. It included a comprehensive number of profiles of leading proponents of management theory, from early pioneers such as [[Charles Babbage]] and [[Frederick Winslow Taylor]], to those such as [[Seebohm Rowntree]] and [[Mary Parker Follett]] who innovated and refined their concepts.
All aimed to bring '"adequate intelligence" to the control of the forces released by a mechanised economy' to bring the logical standards of science to bear on business practice. It also dealt with early contributions to understanding the scientific approach to control in industry. A long background of scientific management practices had previously been largely unknown before publication of these volumes. The study included a view of methods of control at the famous [[Boulton and Watt]] Foundry, of [[Robert Owen]]'s approach to personnel management, and of commercial management training.
===The Manager's Span of Control=== Lyndall Urwick was the first writer to apply the concept of [[span of control]] formally to business. Urwick asserted that the reduction of less important daily duties is essential for enhancing the ''personal touch'' that makes a business executive an effective leader.<ref name="Urwick">Urwick, Lyndall F. "[http://www.nickols.us/Span.pdf Manager's Span of Control]." ''Harvard Business Review'' 34.3 (May–June 1956). p. 39-47</ref> Using the work of General Sir [[Ian Standish Monteith Hamilton]], Urwick maintained that limiting the number of subordinates reporting to an executive ( i.e. restricting the span of control) can do the following: improve executive effectiveness; reduce pressure, inefficiency and incompetence; produce better employee co-operation; and build morale and sense of unity within the organisation.<ref name="Urwick" />
After a conversation with Urwick, [[A.V. Graicunas]] wrote an article, "Relationship in Organization", that was published in 1933 in the ''Bulletin'' of the [[International Institute for Management Development|International Management Institute]]. In this article, Graicunas noted that superiors must be cognizant of not only their direct relationships of their subordinates, but the cross relationships between subordinates and different subgroupings.<ref name="Urwick" /> Graicunas went on to apply a mathematical formula to show that each increase of direct relationships by 1 represented a 25% increase in power to delegate and more than a 100% increase in the burden of supervision and co-ordination.<ref name="Urwick" /> Urwick expanded on these findings to provide the recommendation that "no superior can supervise directly the work of more than five or, at the most, six subordinates whose work interlocks".<ref name="Urwick" />
Urwick’s application of the span of control to business was not met without criticism. [[Herbert A. Simon]] questioned the theoretical soundness of the concept and suggested that a restricted span of control would produce excessive red tape.<ref name="Urwick" /> Urwick countered this criticism by noting that if span of control is appropriately implemented this will not occur. [[Burleigh B. Gardner]] criticised span of control as prohibiting democratic participation within the organisation.<ref name="Urwick" /> Urwick countered this criticism by noting that too wide of a span of control reduces democracy because it prevents subordinates from having meaningful interaction with superiors. Additionally, other scholars criticised the principle as incorrect because of examples of efficient organisations that has an expanded span of control. Urwick addressed this criticism by noting that in these situations subordinates' work did not overlock. Therefore, these organisations were exceptions.
Reasons that leaders ignore the principle of span of control were also addressed by Urwick. Three primary "human failings" are described including: the failure of business to distinguish rank or status from function; cost-consciousness of businessmen; and the cherishing of the stereotype of the ''efficient executive''.<ref name="Urwick" /> Urwick noted that effective leaders will overcome these failings and begin to ''lead'' and not ''dominate'' his or her subordinates.<ref name="Urwick" />
=== Management education in Britain === In the 1940s and 1950s Urwick's intellectual interests continued. An increasing concern of his was the lack of management education in Britain. He was involved in the very earliest discussions for what would become, in 1948, the [[Administrative Staff College]].<ref>Yvette Bryan, ''Management Education in England: The Urwick Report'', Exeter University PhD thesis (2009). Online [https://ore.exeter.ac.uk/repository/bitstream/handle/10036/93959/BryanY.pdf?sequence=2 here].</ref> His own view of the education required did not accord with the College as it was finally established, which concentrated on a three-month course for established executives. He would have preferred something much closer to the model of the American [[business school]], involving a longer course and aimed at pre-experience students. It was a continuing frustration for Urwick that England's two ancient universities failed to promote management education.<ref name=OUPUrwick />

Harper & brothers, 1944. * Urwick, Lyndall Fownes. ''Notes on the Theory of Organization.'' New York: American Management Association, 1952. * Urwick, Lyndall Fownes and [[Edward Brech]]. University of Minnesota Press, 1956. * Urwick, Lyndall Fownes. {{Infobox economist | name = Maqbool Dada | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[Americans|American]] | institution = [[Johns Hopkins University]]
[[Purdue University]]
[[Northwestern University]] | field = [[Operations Management]]

[[MIT Sloan School of Management]] (PhD, 1984) }} '''Maqbool Dada''' is a professor at [[Carey Business School]], [[Johns Hopkins University]], with expertise in the areas of [[Operations Management|operations management]], [[healthcare]], and [[marketing]]. He is also a core faculty member at the [[Johns Hopkins School of Medicine]]’s Armstrong Institute for Patient Safety and Quality.{{cite web|title=Armstrong Institute for Patient Safety and Quality Faculty|url=http://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/armstrong_institute/about/collaborate/faculty.html}} ==Career== Maqbool Dada earned his BS in [[Industrial Engineering|industrial engineering]] and [[Operations Research|operations research]] from [[University of California, Berkeley]] in 1978, and PhD in operations management from the [[MIT Sloan School of Management]] in 1984. Prior to joining [[Johns Hopkins University]] in 2009, Dada served as Professor of Management at [[Krannert School of Management]], [[Purdue University]]. He was also on the faculty of [[Kellogg School of Management]], [[Northwestern University]], and [[University of Illinois at Chicago]].{{cite web | url=http://carey.jhu.edu/one/2008/fall/meet-the-new-faculty-2008-fall/ | title=Meet the New Faculty | publisher = ONE Magazine | accessdate =10 October 2013}} ==Academic work== Dada is known for his work in s[[Supply Chain Management|upply chain management]], [[pricing]], [[inventory theory]], and [[healthcare]]. He serves or has served on the editorial board of major operations management journals, including [[Management Science (journal)|Management Science]], [[Manufacturing & Service Operations Management]], IIE Transactions, and [[Production and Operations Management|Productions and Operations Management]]. His research paper entitled "Pricing and the Newsvendor Problem" and published in 1999, is the No.1 most read article and the No. 7 most cited in the [[Operations Research (journal)|Operations Research]] journal,{{cite web | url=http://pubsonline.informs.org/action/showMostReadArticles?journalCode=opre | title=Most Read Articles | publisher = INFORMS | date = 19 December 2015 | accessdate = 19 December 2015 }}{{cite web| url= http://pubsonline.informs.org/action/showMostCitedArticles?journalCode=opre | title= Most Cited Articles | publisher=INFORMS | date = 19 December 2015 | accessdate = 19 December 2015}} and has been cited more than 1,600 times as of January 2018.{{cite web | url=https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=HgGpAioAAAAJ&hl=en&oi=ao | title= Maqbool Dada - Google Scholar Citations" | date = 22 January 2018 | accessdate = 22 January 2018}} Another paper co-authored by Dada, entitled "A newsvendor’s Procurement Problem when Suppliers Are Unreliable" and published in 2007, is the No. 3 most cited article in the [[Manufacturing & Service Operations Management]] journal.{{cite web | url=http://pubsonline.informs.org/action/showMostCitedArticles?journalCode=msom | title= M&SOM: Most Cited Articles | author= M&SOM | publisher=INFORMS | date = 18 December 2015 | accessdate = 18 December 2015 }} ==Areas of research== ===Operations strategy=== Dada's research covers various aspects of operations strategy, in particular, pricing, postponement, and learning. His papers "Pricing and the Newsvendor Problem: A Review with Extensions"{{Cite journal | last1 = Petruzzi | first1 = N. C. | last2 = Dada | first2 = M. | doi = 10.1287/opre.47.2.183 | title = Pricing and the Newsvendor Problem: A Review with Extensions | journal = Operations Research | volume = 47 | issue = 2 | pages = 183 | year = 1999 | pmid = | pmc = }} and "Price Versus Production Postponement: Capacity and Competition"{{Cite journal | last1 = Van Mieghem | first1 = J. A. | last2 = Dada | first2 = M. | doi = 10.1287/mnsc.45.12.1631 | title = Price Versus Production Postponement: Capacity and Competition | journal = Management Science | volume = 45 | issue = 12 | pages = 1639 | year = 1999 | pmid = | pmc = }} are among the most cited papers on operations strategy. In 2010, his 2007 paper "A Newsvendor's Procurement Problem When Suppliers are Unreliable,"{{Cite journal | last1 = Dada | first1 = M. | last2 = Petruzzi | first2 = N. C. | last3 = Schwarz | first3 = L. B. | title = A Newsvendor's Procurement Problem when Suppliers Are Unreliable | doi = 10.1287/msom.1060.0128 | journal = Manufacturing & Service Operations Management | volume = 9 | pages = 9 | year = 2007 | pmid = | pmc = }} published in [[Manufacturing & Service Operations Management]], was selected as a finalist for the M&SOM Best Paper Award.{{cite web |url=https://www.informs.org/Pubs/MSOM/M-SOM-Best-Paper-Award |title=M&SOM Best Paper Award |publisher=INFORMS |accessdate=10 October 2013 }} ===Healthcare=== Dada's research in healthcare initially focused on reimbursement policy, for example, on [[Medicare (United States)|Medicare]] [[prospective payment system]],{{Cite journal | last1 = Dada | first1 = M. | last2 = White | first2 = W. D. | doi = 10.1287/mnsc.45.3.316 | title = Evaluating Financial Risk in the Medicare Prospective Payment System | journal = Management Science | volume = 45 | issue = 3 | pages = 316 | year = 1999 | pmid = | pmc = }}{{Cite journal | last1 = Dada | first1 = M. | last2 = White | first2 = W. D. | last3 = Stokes | first3 = H. H. | last4 = Kurzeja | first4 = P. | title = Prospective Payment for Psychiatric Services | doi = 10.1215/03616878-17-3-483 | journal = Journal of Health Politics, Policy and Law | volume = 17 | issue = 3 | pages = 483 | year = 1992 | pmid = | pmc = }} and later shifted toward applications of Operations Management to healthcare delivery.{{Cite journal | last1 = Williams | first1 = K. A. | last2 = Chambers | first2 = C. G. | last3 = Dada | first3 = M. | last4 = Hough | first4 = D. | last5 = Aron | first5 = R. | last6 = Ulatowski | first6 = J. A. | doi = 10.1097/ALN.0b013e31824a88d0 | title = Using Process Analysis to Assess the Impact of Medical Education on the Delivery of Pain Services | journal = Anesthesiology | volume = 116 | issue = 4 | pages = 931–939 | year = 2012 | pmid = 22329970| pmc = }}{{cite web | title=Designing Cyclic Schedules for Outpatient Appointments in an Academic Medical Center | publisher = umn.edu | date = 24 October 2012 | accessdate = 20 December 2013 | url =http://www.isye.umn.edu/events/pdf/Dada.pdf }} He has also worked on global health issues, including, for example, expanding capacity in women's reproductive health care in [[Sierra Leone]] to reduce maternal morbidity and mortality, supported by an Alliance for a Healthier World at Johns Hopkins Award.{{cite web|title=Alliance for a Healthier World at Johns Hopkins awards grants to eight interdisciplinary teams|url=https://hub.jhu.edu/2017/10/12/alliance-for-a-healthier-world-grant-awards/|website=The Hub|publisher=Johns Hopkins University|accessdate=22 January 2018|language=en|date=12 October 2017}} ===Marketing-operations interfaces=== Dada is among the pioneering researchers in the field of [[marketing]]-[[Operations Management|operations]] interfaces. In this area, his research covers various topics including durable goods,{{Cite journal | last1 = Dada | first1 = M. | last2 = Srikanth | first2 = K. N. | doi = 10.1287/opre.38.4.656 | title = Monopolistic Pricing and the Learning Curve: An Algorithmic Approach | journal = Operations Research | volume = 38 | issue = 4 | pages = 656 | year = 1990 | pmid = | pmc = }} demand substitution,{{Cite journal | last1 = Anupindi | first1 = R. | last2 = Dada | first2 = M. | last3 = Gupta | first3 = S. | doi = 10.1287/mksc.17.4.406 | title = Estimation of Consumer Demand with Stock-Out Based Substitution: An Application to Vending Machine Products | journal = Marketing Science | volume = 17 | issue = 4 | pages = 406 | year = 1998 | pmid = | pmc = }} distribution and pricing,{{Cite journal | last1 = Dada | first1 = M. | last2 = Srikanth | first2 = K. N. | doi = 10.1287/mnsc.33.10.1247 | title = Pricing Policies for Quantity Discounts | journal = Management Science | volume = 33 | issue = 10 | pages = 1247 | year = 1987 | pmid = | pmc = }} and consumers' waiting experience.{{Cite journal | last1 = Kumar | first1 = P. | last2 = Kalwani | first2 = M. U. | last3 = Dada | first3 = M. | doi = 10.1287/mksc.16.4.295 | title = The Impact of Waiting Time Guarantees on Customers' Waiting Experiences | journal = Marketing Science | volume = 16 | issue = 4 | pages = 295 | year = 1997 | pmid = | pmc = }} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://carey.jhu.edu/faculty-research/directory/maqbool-dada-phd/ Dada's Johns Hopkins Homepage ] {{DEFAULTSORT:Dada, Maqbool}} [[Category:American business theorists]] [[Category:American operations researchers]] [[Category:MIT Sloan School of Management alumni]] [[Category:Johns Hopkins University faculty]] [[Category:Johns Hopkins University people]] [[Category:Krannert School of Management faculty]] [[Category:American social scientists]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:University of California, Berkeley College of Engineering alumni]]
