{{Infobox company | name = SBB Cargo International | logo = Logo-sbb-cargo.gif | caption = | type = | genre = | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = <!-- {{Start date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | founder = | defunct = | location_city = [[Olten]] | location_country = [[Switzerland]] | location = | locations = | area_served = | key_people = | industry = Rail freight | products = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | traded_as = | homepage = {{URL|http://www.sbbcargo-international.com/index.php?id=de&L=2|www.sbbcargo-international.com}} | footnotes = | intl = }} '''SBB Cargo International''' is a rail transport business founded as a joint venture between [[SBB Cargo]] and [[Hupac]]<ref>{{cite web |url = http://mct.sbb.ch/mct/en/cargo-news.htm?cmd=E2B9CC475D6FBB37CF7A85C1754870B1 |archive-url = https://archive.is/20130101172706/http://mct.sbb.ch/mct/en/cargo-news.htm?cmd=E2B9CC475D6FBB37CF7A85C1754870B1 |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 2013-01-01 |accessdate = 2010-09-26 |title = SBB: Cargo - News |date = 2010-09-26 }}</ref> The headquarters will be at [[Olten]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.railwaygazette.com/nc/news/single-view/view/news-in-brief-40.html |accessdate=2010-09-26 |title=Railway Gazette: News in Brief }}</ref> handling international rail freight in Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uic.org/com/uic-e-news/197/article/new-sbb-cargo-and-hupac-joint |accessdate=2010-10-26 |title=New SBB Cargo and Hupac joint venture: SBB Cargo International - UIC Communications |date=2010-10-26 }}</ref> SBB Cargo International is due to commence operations at the start of 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hupac.com/en/index.php?p=presse_2010/5_7_2010/5_7_2010&ml=&mt=6 |accessdate=2010-09-26 |title=.: HUPAC :. }}</ref>
==History== Following the failure of SBB's plans to strengthen the profitability and financial independence of its Cargo division by selling stakes to other international railway operators, SBB Cargo changed to an alternative solution. A new railway undertaking called SBB Cargo International was founded in partnership with intermodal transport operator [[Hupac]]. The new company focuses on block and intermodal trains on the European North-South corridor between [[Germany]] and [[Italy]]. The shareholders in the new company are SBB Cargo (75%) and Hupac (25%), with further partners possible in the future. The aim is to achieve cost leadership in the [[Intermodal freight transport|intermodal]] segment by optimising resources on selected routes and halving structural costs. The new company’s customers will primarily comprise intermodal operators, who will account for about 80% of the planned total sales of CHF 300 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.railwaygazette.com/nc/news/single-view/view/sbb-and-hupac-to-form-trans-alpine-freight-operator.html |accessdate=2010-10-26 |title=Railway Gazette: SBB and Hupac to form trans-Alpine freight operator }}</ref>
==Fleet== SBB Cargo International will, initially, lease 109 [[locomotive]]s from SBB Cargo; 59 will be [[multi-system locomotive]]s for cross-border use.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldcargonews.com/htm/w20100706.330340.htm |accessdate=2010-09-26 |title=SBB Cargo International founded Hupac,SBB Cargo, Acquisition and mergers,Intermodal and multimodal operators,Railways and rail operators,Europe, Kunz, Bernhard,Perrin, Nicholas, |date=2010-09-26 }}</ref>

'''Shop stewards''' are representatives of [[labour unions]]. Unlike other [[union representative|union representatives]], stewards work on the shop floor, connecting workers with union officials at regional or national levels.
The role of shop stewards may vary from being a mere representative of a larger national union towards independent structures with the power of collective bargaining on the workplace.
Both in [[Germany]] and [[United Kingdom|Britain]]{{fact|date=September 2017}} shop stewards were crucial{{fact|date=September 2017}} in antiwar protests during World War I. In Germany a network of shop stewards called [[Revolutionary Stewards]] took an important role in the revolutionary events of November 9 in Berlin.<ref>Ralf Hoffrogge, ''Working-Class Politics in the German Revolution. Richard Müller, the Revolutionary Shop Stewards and the Origins of the Council Movement'', Brill Publications 2014, {{ISBN|978-9-00421-921-2}}., pp. 21-31.</ref>
==Literature== * John Benson, ''Unions at the Workplace: Shop Steward Leadership and Ideology'', 1991. * Ralf Hoffrogge, ''Working-Class Politics in the German Revolution. Richard Müller, the Revolutionary Shop Stewards and the Origins of the Council Movement'', Brill Publications 2014, {{ISBN|978-9-00421-921-2}}. * Y. Rittau and T. Dundon, 2010, The roles and functions of shop stewards in workplace partnership: evidence from the Republic of Ireland, Employee Relations, Vol 32(1), p. 10-27.

| industry = [[Personal care]] and [[food]] | products = | production = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = {{URL|www.splash.com.ph}} | footnotes = }} '''Splash Corporation''' ([[Doing business as|d/b/a]] '''Splash''') is a [[Philippines|Filipino]] [[personal care]] and [[food]] company based in [[Bonifacio Global City]], [[Taguig]]. == History == Splash Corporation was founded in 1985 by Drs. Rolando and Rosalinda Hortaleza and incorporated as RBH Cosmetics, the company’s very first products were repackaged acetone and cuticle remover as just a backyard business when decided to invest their ₱12,000 cash gifts from their wedding. In 1987, Hortaleza seeing a fad in growing hair-style decided to sell high-quality but affordable hair spray, letting the company earned its first one million peso in sales. The couple eventually renamed their company from Hortaleza Cosmetics to Splash Cosmetics. In 1993, the Hortalezas were able to afford sophisticated technologies and it was renamed as Splash Manufacturing Corporation. In 1997, the Splash Research Institute was established complete with state-of-the-art facilities and equipment, and a research staff of more than 20 chemists, pharmacists and engineers. Its main purpose is to design and develop of innovative products and packaging systems. Splash tries to keep a two-year rolling pipeline of new products, backed by rigid clinical tests. In 2001, Splash Manufacturing Corporation was renamed as Splash Corporation and in 2002, Splash invested in a ₱400 million state-of-the-art manufacturing complex in Canumay, [[Valenzuela, Philippines|Valenzuela]] which is expected to meet the company's capacity requirements in the medium-term. On November 15, 2007, the Splash’s shares of stocks were listed in the [[Philippine Stock Exchange]] under the stock symbol, SPH. In 2009, the company made three major moves. P.T. Splash Cahaya was incorporated in Indonesia as part of company’s expansion overseas. On November, the company went into the direct selling business by launching the First Business Center. A month later, Splash established the Acceleron Distribution Corporation to distribute certain brands to large-scale supermarkets. In 2011, Splash acquired Barrio Fiesta Manufacturing Corporation (BFMC) for ₱472 million to gain a foothold in the food industry through the Barrio Fiesta branded shrimp paste, recipe mixes and flavored vinegar.{{cite web | url=http://www.splash.com.ph/index.php/splash-acquires-barrio-fiesta-brand-for-p472m/ | title=Splash board approves P69-million spending budget for 2015 | publisher=Business World|date=December 19, 2014| accessdate=May 6, 2015}} In 2012, it acquired Moondish Corporation with its canned line of ready to eat canned products.{{cite web | url=http://www.philstar.com/business/2012/09/15/849102/splash-gobbles-another-food-firm | title=Splash gobbles up another food firm | publisher=[[The Philippine Star|philstar.com]] |date=September 14, 2012 | accessdate=April 18, 2015}}{{cite web | url=http://www.rappler.com/business/13388-splash-expands-food-portfolio,-buys-moondish | title=Splash expands food portfolio, buys Moondish| publisher= [[Rappler]] | date=October 1, 2012 | accessdate=November 2, 2015}} As of December 2013, Splash Corporation, ranks fifth in the personal care industry, outranked only by giant multinationals and making the number one personal care company in the Philippines. == Brands == === Food === * Barrio Fiesta * Moondish * Crispy Joy * Barrio Fiesta Peanut Butter * Coconut Water === Personal hygiene === * Stylex (formerly Control) * Flawlessly U (formerly Extract) * Hygienix * Kolours * Maxi-Peel * Shades by Kolours * SkinWhite * Splash Direct Sales * Vitress == References == {{reflist}} == External {{underconstruction}} A timeline of notable events relating to [[Bauer Radio]], a British media company founded in 2007.
==2000s== *'''2008''' ** 29 January – [[Bauer Media Group|Bauer]] completes its purchase of [[Emap]]'s radio, television and consumer media businesses, purchasing the assets for £1.14bn.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.campaignlive.co.uk/article/772251/emap-sells-magazines-radio-divisions-bauer-114bn# | title = Emap sells magazines and radio divisions to Bauer for £1.14bn | publisher =Campaign Live | date = 7 December 2007|accessdate=11 June 2016 }}</ref>
*'''2009''' **No events.
==2010s== *'''2010''' **No events.
*'''2011''' **No events.
*'''2012''' **8 June – [[Bauer Radio]] stations [[kiss (UK radio station)|Kiss]] and [[Heat Radio|Heat]] carry the first in a series of live adverts for a new TV show on [[Channel 4]]. The ''heat4…Live!'' social TV experiences are three live dual screen events, with the first centred around the ''[[Hollyoaks Savage Party]]'' special.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://radiotoday.co.uk/2012/05/bauer-to-air-live-radio-commercials/|title= Bauer to air live radio commercials|first= Roy|last= Martin|publisher= Radio Today|date= 30 May 2012|accessdate= 31 May 2012}}</ref>
*'''2013''' **6 February – [[Bauer Media]] buys the digital station [[Planet Rock (radio station)|Planet Rock]] for a sum estimated to be between £1m and £2m.<ref>{{cite news|first=John |last=Plunkett |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2013/feb/06/planet-rock-bauer-media |title=Planet Rock bought by Bauer Media |publisher=Guardian Media Group |newspaper=The Guardian |date=6 February 2013 |accessdate=9 February 2013}}</ref> **15 April – [[Bauer Radio|Bauer]] increases networking on its Yorkshire Magic stations with a networked breakfast show coming from [[Magic 828]] in [[Leeds]].<ref>[http://radiotoday.co.uk/2013/04/bauer-networks-three-more-magic-stations/ Bauer networks three more Magic stations]</ref> **1 July – Bauer's Scottish MW stations start to receive a networked breakfast show form [[Glasgow]] presented by [[Robin Galloway]]. Consequently, there is now no local programming on any of these stations.<ref>[http://radiotoday.co.uk/2013/06/galloway-goes-national-at-bauer-scotland/ Galloway goes national at Bauer Scotland], Radio Today, 3 June 2013</ref>
*'''2014''' **No events.
*'''2015''' **5 January – ***[[Magic Radio]] launches nationally on [[Digital One]], while all Magic AM stations in the north of England are rebranded as [[Bauer City 2|City Network 2]]. ***[[Absolute Radio]] changes from broadcasting in stereo to mono to make way for Magic on DAB.<ref>{{cite news|last=Martin |first=Roy |url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2015/01/bauer-puts-magic-on-d1-puts-absolute-in-mono/ |title=Bauer puts Magic on D1, puts Absolute in mono |publisher=Radio Today |date=5 January 2015 |accessdate=7 January 2015}}</ref> **31 March – [[Ofcom]] launches an investigation into [[Bauer Media]] and [[Absolute Radio]] for an alleged breach of its regulations, but no details of the incident are to be released until the investigation is complete.<ref>{{cite news|last=Martin |first=Roy |url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2015/03/ofcom-launches-absolute-radio-investigation/ |title=Ofcom launches Absolute Radio investigation |publisher=Radio Today |date=30 March 2015 |accessdate=31 March 2015}}</ref> **7 December – Following permission from the regulator, Bauer swaps Radio City 2's format and frequencies with that of [[Radio City Talk]]. This gives [[Bauer City 2|City Network 2]] its first berth on FM in England.<ref>[http://radiotoday.co.uk/2015/07/radio-city-wants-to-swap-am-fm-services/ Radio City wants to swap AM & FM services], RadioToday, 21 July 2015</ref><ref>[http://radiotoday.co.uk/2015/11/date-set-for-radio-city-2-and-3-frequency-swap/ Date set for Radio City 2 and 3 frequency swap], RadioToday, 16 November 2015</ref>
*'''2016''' **15 March – [[Mellow Magic]] and [[Talksport 2]] begin broadcasting on the Sound Digital multiplex. They are joined on the multiplex on 21 March by [[Talkradio]], on the 28th by [[Magic Chilled]] and on the 30th by [[Virgin Radio UK|Virgin Radio]]. **6 May – [[Orion Media]] announces that they have been bought by [[Bauer Media Group|Bauer]] for an undisclosed fee, reportedly between £40 and £50 million.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/06/bauer-buys-radio-group-orion-media Bauer buys radio group Orion Media], The Guardian, 6 May 2016</ref><ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2016/05/06/orion-media-sold-to-bauer-for-50m/ Orion Media sold to Bauer for £50m], The Telegraph, 6 May 2016</ref> This gives Bauer the West Midlands network of [[Free Radio (network)|Free Radio stations]] and East Midlands regional station [[Gem 106]].
*'''2017''' **3 January – [[Bauer Radio]]'s Cash for Kids appeal raises £15.5 million for charity.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2017/01/15-5m-raised-for-children-in-poverty-by-bauer/ |title=£15.5m raised for children in poverty by Bauer |publisher=Radio Today |date=3 January 2017 |accessdate=21 January 2017}}</ref>
*'''2018''' **3 April – [[Aberdeen]] station [[Northsound 2]] stops broadcasting on MW. The station continues to broadcast on DAB and online. It becomes the first commercial radio station in Scotland – and the first of Bauer's local stations – to cease analogue broadcasting.<ref>[https://radiotoday.co.uk/2018/03/northsound-2-to-switch-off-am-radio-service/ Northsound 2 to switch off AM radio service], Radio Today, 8 March 2018</ref> **18 April – [[Bauer Radio]] announces that, on 4 June its [[Manchester]] station [[Key 103]] will be rebranded and relaunched as ''Hits Radio'', a [[Contemporary Hit Radio|CHR]]-led music station aimed at 25–44 year olds.<ref>[http://www.bauermedia.co.uk/newsroom/press/bauer-to-launch-new-national-radio-station Bauer to launch new national radio station] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180419120805/http://www.bauermedia.co.uk/newsroom/press/bauer-to-launch-new-national-radio-station |date=2018-04-19 }}, Bauer Media, 18 April 2018</ref> The station will be merged with [[The Hits Radio|The Hits]] to provide a single national service across the UK on DAB, Freeview and online.<ref>[https://www.prolificnorth.co.uk/news/broadcasting/2018/04/key-103-become-hits-radio-part-major-rebrand Key 103 to become Hits Radio as part of major rebrand] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180419121220/https://www.prolificnorth.co.uk/news/broadcasting/2018/04/key-103-become-hits-radio-part-major-rebrand |date=2018-04-19 }}, Prolific North, 18 April 2018</ref> In Manchester, Hits Radio will continue to provide local news and information, traffic bulletins and advertising.<ref>[https://radiotoday.co.uk/2018/04/key-103-to-rebrand-as-hits-radio-and-go-national/ Key 103 to rebrand as Hits Radio and go national] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180419053126/https://radiotoday.co.uk/2018/04/key-103-to-rebrand-as-hits-radio-and-go-national/ |date=2018-04-19 }}, Radio Today, 19 April 2018</ref> ''Hits Radio'' will also produce and broadcast off-peak programming for [[Bauer City 1|Bauer's network of CHR local stations]] which will continue to air local programming at peak times. **25 May – Ahead of the launch of [[Bauer City 1|Hits Radio]] on 4 June, the name [[Key 103]] disappears from the [[Manchester]] airwaves. **4 June – Key 2 is renamed Key Radio. **16 August – [[Bauer Radio]] purchases [[Jazz FM (UK)|Jazz FM]].<ref>{{cite news|first=Roy |last=Martin |url=https://radiotoday.co.uk/2018/08/bauer-media-group-agrees-to-acquire-jazz-fm/ |title=Bauer Media Group agrees to acquire Jazz FM |publisher=Radio Today |date=16 August 2018 |accessdate=16 August 2018}}</ref>
*'''2019''' **7 January – [[Greatest Hits Radio Network|Greatest Hits Radio]] will replace the Bauer City 2 branding. Individual station identities in Northern England will be rebranded to GHR with Scotland unaffected. It will also become available across the West Midlands for the first time.<ref>[https://www.bauermedia.co.uk/newsroom/press-releases/bauer-media-to-launch-the-greatest-hits-radio-network BAUER MEDIA TO LAUNCH THE GREATEST HITS RADIO NETWORK] Bauer Media, 15 November 2018</ref><ref>[https://radiotoday.co.uk/2018/11/bauer-media-to-launch-greatest-hits-radio-network/ Bauer Media to launch Greatest Hits Radio network] Radio Today, 15 November 2018</ref> Other changes will see the closure of [[Free Radio 80s]] close with some of its frequencies transferred to [[Absolute Classic Rock]].

王惕吾 |birth_name = 王瑞鐘 |birth_date = {{birth date|1913|08|29|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Dongyang]], [[Zhejiang]], [[Republican China]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1996|3|11|1913|08|29|df=y}} |death_place = [[Taiwan]] |known_for = |occupation = Founder and leading publisher of the ''[[United Daily News]]'', Kuomintang politician and humanitarian |alma_mater = Zhejiang Dongyang High School |parents = |spouse = 趙玉仙 |children = 5 |relatives = [[Shaw-Lan Wang]](daughter) }} '''Wang Tiwu''' ({{zh|c=王惕吾}}, 29 August 1913 - 11 March 1996, born in [[Dongyang]], [[Zhejiang]], China) is the founder of the [[United Daily News]] and was a member of the Chinese Kuomintang Central Standing Committee. ==Notable Events== Wang's family are from [[Zhejiang]].{{cite web | url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/e51ded38-5706-11e1-be25-00144feabdc0.html#axzz2YgEuTxEl | title=Lunch with the FT: Shaw-Lan Wang | publisher=Financial Times | date=February 17, 2012 | accessdate=10 July 2013 | author=Pilling, David}} In 1947, Wang was a colonel in the army of Chiang Kai-shek, traveled to Taiwan, and founded the newspaper [[United Daily News]]. His daughter, [[Shaw-Lan Wang]], currently owns and runs [[United Daily News]]. ==Personal life == Wang had 5 children. The eldest daughter [[Shaw-Lan Wang]] is also an active publisher, the boss of fashion house [[Lanvin (company)|Lanvin]] and humanitarian. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:1913 births]] [[Category:1996 deaths]] [[Category:Taiwanese businesspeople]] [[Category:Politicians from Jinhua]] [[Category:Kuomintang politicians in Taiwan]] [[Category:Republic of China politicians from Zhejiang]] [[Category:Taiwanese humanitarians]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Zhejiang]] [[Category:Taiwanese people from Zhejiang]] {{Taiwan-business-bio-stub}}

[[File:Yeshe Choesang.jpg|thumb|Yeshe Choesang]] Yeshe Choesang is a India-based Tibetan journalist, photographer and author who focuses on politics, Freedom of press, business, human rights and environmental issues in Tibet and China.
== Biography == '''Yeshe Choesang''' (Tibetan: ཡེ་ཤེས་ཆོས་བཟང་། Chinese: 益西曲桑 Hindi: यीशि छोसं), pronounced [ˈyeːshey ˈchoe: Zang]), born in 1974 in [[Lithang]] Region in eastern [[Tibet]], is a Tibetan journalist, founder and editor in chief of [[Tibet Post|The Tibet Post]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thetibetpost.com/|title=Tibet News - Tibet post International|website=Tibet post International|accessdate=6 August 2018}}</ref> an exiled Tibetan news Agency based in [[Dharamsala, Himachal Pradesh|Dharamsala]], [[India]].
Mr Choesang was born on 18 August 1974 in the [[Lithang]] Region in eastern [[Tibet]], (Currently administratively part of [[Sichuan]] province, China). He escaped to [[India]] in 1985.
=== Education === He completed his education in [[Tibetan culture]] and [[Tibetan Buddhism|religion]] (The ''Rigne Rabjam'') in 1993 and a teacher training course of the Tibetan Education Department in 1995. He completed his [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] in Tibetan [[Buddhist Philosophy]] from the Institute of Buddhist Dialectics (IBD).<ref name="OT-about">{{cite web|url=http://www.outlooktibet.com/about-outlooktibet|title=Outlook Tibet|website=www.outlooktibet.com|accessdate=6 August 2018}}</ref>
In 2000, he was the assistant editor of ''How To Teach'', a bilingual teacher training book series in [[Standard Tibetan|Tibetan]] and [[English language|English]] for Tibetan teachers. For 4 years, he worked as a researcher in [[World History]] at the Research & Translation Centre (Lhaksam Tsekpa) of IBD.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://secrettibet.rsfblog.org/about.html|title=About|publisher=|accessdate=6 August 2018}}</ref>
=== Media career === Choesang wrote several articles in the past 10 years that were published by [[Tibet Post]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thetibetpost.com/en/outlook/opinions-and-columns/4350-everyday-is-human-rights-day-a-new-hope-for-tibetans-in-tibet|title=Everyday is Human Rights Day: A new hope for Tibetans in Tibet? - Tibet post International|first=Yeshe Choesang, Tibet Post|last=International|date=16 December 2014|publisher=|accessdate=6 August 2018}}</ref> [[CNN iReport]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ireport.cnn.com/docs/DOC-1239094|title=Genocide in the 20th Century: Massacres in Tibet: 1966-76|website=CNN iReport|accessdate=6 August 2018}}</ref> [[Deliberation]],<ref>[http://www.deliberation.info/author/yeshe/]</ref> and [[World News Network]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://search.wn.com/?template=cheetah-search-adv/index.txt&action=search&results_type=news&search_string=Yeshe+Choesang&language_id=1&sort_type=-pub-datetime&corpus=current&search_type=expression|title=Yeshe Choesang - WN.COM advanced search|website=search.wn.com|accessdate=6 August 2018}}</ref>
Choesang has written a book titled "Voice of An Exiled Tibetan: Hopes of freedom and struggle" was published in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.in/books/about/Voice_of_An_Exiled_Tibetan.html?id=oxrLBQAAQBAJ&redir_esc=y|title=Voice of An Exiled Tibetan: Hopes of freedom and struggle|first=Yeshe|last=Choesang|date=10 December 2014|publisher=Yeshe Choesang|accessdate=6 August 2018|via=Google Books}}</ref> He is writing a second book, but title yet to be named.
He was elected thrice as the General Secretary of the [[Association of Tibetan Journalists]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tibetanjournalists.org/about/members_directory.html|title=about us|publisher=|accessdate=6 August 2018}}</ref> based in Dharamsala. He is the Tibet Correspondent for [[Reporters Without Borders]] since 2005.<ref>[http://fr.rsf.org/chine-plus-de-dix-mille-signatures-en-29-07-2009,33992 Plus de dix mille signatures en faveur du réalisateur Dhondup Wangchen]</ref>
In 2007 Choesang founded [[Tibet Post Dharamsala|The Tibet Post International]] (TPI), a daily Tibetan news agency based in [[McLeod Ganj]], [[Dharamsala, Himachal Pradesh|Dharamsala]]. Other than this, he has also founded several other websites, like outlooktibet.com, shambalapost.com and lhasapost.com. The office of TPI was inaugurated on 11 May 2008 by [[Franz Pahl]], a member of [[South Tyrolean People's Party]] and President of the regional parliament of [[South Tyrol]] in [[Italy]].<ref name="TPI-inaug">{{cite web|url=http://tibetpost.net/old/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=550&Itemid=69|title=South Tyrol Parliamentary President inaugurated The Tibet Post International|publisher=|accessdate=6 August 2018}}</ref>
In 2010, he also founded Himalayan Literacy Trust (HLT) in India.<ref name="OT-about" />
=== Community development === With HLT and TPI Choesang aims to develop Tibetan media and education in a peaceful and non-violent manner. His organisations also function as a platform to enable future development of Tibetan journalism, doing so by coordinating a group of young Tibetan journalists with the primary goal of promoting [[democracy]] through [[freedom of expression]] within Tibetan communities, both in exile and under occupation in Tibet.<ref name="TPI-inaug" />
With TPI Choesang works in cooperation with [[non-governmental organization]]s and individuals around the world as well as with the various departments of the [[Central Tibetan Administration]] while dealing at the same time with individuals and societies in various [[Tibetan diaspora|Tibetan settlements]] and schools.<ref name="TPI-inaug" />
